STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 2, 2022,
Stephanie Dettloff
Child & Family Services - Northeast Michigan
1044 US-23 N
Alpena, MI 49707
RE: License #: CB040201041
Child & Family Services - Northeast Michigan
1044 US-23 N
Alpena, MI 49707
Dear Ms. Dettloff:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 02/18/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Mark R. Hunter, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 395-2847
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
The caseload information received indicated a foster care worker currently has a
caseload of 21. In my interviews with the foster care worker and an adoption
worker, they both reported carrying a caseload in excess of the workload standard
established by this rule due to staff turnover and difficulty in recruiting replacement
staff. I have had communications with administration as they attempt to recruit staff
and facilitate the possibility of obtaining variances to meet the staffing needs.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
Two of the three new staff personnel records submitted did not include
documentation of any references and one of the three records only included 2
references.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
3

One of the three new staff personnel records submitted did not include
documentation that a criminal records clearance (ICHAT) had been completed as
required by this rule.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of the three new staff personnel records submitted did not include
documentation that a central registry clearance had been completed as required by
this rule. This was the same record that did not include a criminal record clearance.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation.
The placement specifications shall include all of the following:
(a) Age,
(b) Gender,
(c) Race,
(d) Number of children preferred by the family,
(e) Characteristics of children best served by the home,
(f) Children who may not be placed in the home. The child's
racial, ethnic, and cultural identity, heritage, and background
may only be considered if an assessment of the individual child
indicates that such consideration is in the best interests of the
child.
One of the three current foster home files reviewed contained a reevaluation report
dated 11/01/2021 that did not document the placement specifications as required by
this rule. The report contained a generic statement to “continue with no change”
instead of indicating the characteristics as required. The entire rule is cited because
the general statement did not identify any of the characteristics required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
4

Two of the three special evaluations reviewed contained reports that included the
last name of a child placed in the home that was interviewed as a part of the
evaluation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
Two of the three special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation to
indicate the foster parent was provided a copy of the report as required by this rule.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Two of the three special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation to
indicate the foster parent was informed in writing they could have a written response
included as an attachment to the report as required by this rule.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Two of the three special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation to
indicate the social service worker with children placed in the home was provided a
copy of the report as required by this rule.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child's record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
Two of the three foster child records reviewed indicated the foster child had a
change in placement and the documentation of the change as required by this rule
was not located. In the first example the youth had a change in placement on
05/02/21 and on 06/21/21 and the required documentation for each of these
changes could not be located. The second youth had a change in placement
07/18/21 and the documentation for this change could not be located at the time of
this review.
5

R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of the records for three youth who were discharged from a foster home did not
have the change in placement documentation completed that included all of the
information required by this rule. The documentation did not include a summary of
the services provided or the provision for any continuing services.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of the three current foster child records reviewed had an updated service plan
that was not completed within the timeline established by this rule. In this example
the report for the time period ending 12/13/2021 had not yet been completed at the
time of this review. It was indicated that the report was only “in progress”.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED 12/02/2020 Renewal, CAP Approved
12/17/2020
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of the three current foster child records reviewed indicated the youth had not
received an initial physical exam as required by this rule. In this example the youth
6

had a documented physical dated 03/12/2020 with an updated physical exam due
to be completed by 05/12/2021. There was no documentation the updated physical
exam had been completed at the time of this review.
One of the three current foster child records reviewed documented an initial dental
exam had been completed within the time frame established by this rule. In this
example an initial dental exam was due by 08/25/2021 and there was no
documentation the initial dental had been completed at the time of this review.
There was also no documentation a dental exam had been completed within 12
months prior to placement.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Two of the four applicants for adoption files who had recommendations for denial
did not have documentation the applicants were given a copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion. Documentation that a 605 form was sent to
the applicants was used to determine compliance/noncompliance. Two of the four
files did not document this form was sent to the applicants.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an
operational statewide automated child welfare information
system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary tracking
system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
The MISACWIS information reviewed as a part of this interim evaluation indicated
there was some missing information not uploaded into the information system as
required. Some examples of the missing information were PATPs with signatures,
one youth picture, one adoption closing summary, two adoption closing summaries
that did not include signatures, and one special evaluation report.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
7

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
The need to have documents signed within 30 days of the document’s completion.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan for a special evaluation
completed 10/25/2021. Noncompliance with 421(b) was determined and the
corrective action plan was approved 12/15/2021. The renewal evaluation completed
12/02/2020 determined noncompliance with 212(3)(a), 418(2)(b), 413(1)(c)(ii),(f)(ii),
ISEP 6.33, ISEP4.49, FOM 722 -08 C, -06H, 06B, -15. The corrective action plan
for the renewal evaluation was approved 12/17/2020. A repeat noncompliance with
418(2)(b) was identified as a part of this interim evaluation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment primarily consisted of a review in the progress of
the agency to implement the corrective action plan associated with the renewal
evaluation completed in December 2020. The assessment indicated progress had been
made but was limited due to two primary challenges. One challenge was associated
with COVID related circumstances and the second challenge associated with the
agency to maintain sufficient staffing numbers.
Interviews
Child welfare staff was involved in the entrance conference. Foster Care and
Adoption/Certification staff were interviewed by telephone with the only concerns noted
being caseload size associated with the difficulty related to staff recruitment.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: Recommended a relative home attach safety features to doors exiting
the home.
8

Resolution: Alarms were purchased by the agency and were installed 12/20/2021.
Documentation including pictures confirming installation was received 01/04/2022.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
02/25/2022
________________________________________
Mark R. Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
3/2/21
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
